data.q: What is the main purpose of Web Workers in the browser?
o: To run JavaScript in background threads
data.explanation: Web Workers allow JavaScript to run in background threads, preventing blocking of the main UI thread.

data.q: Which method is used to create a new Web Worker?
data.explanation: A new Web Worker is created using the constructor new Worker('script.js').

data.q: How do Web Workers communicate with the main thread?
data.explanation: Web Workers communicate with the main thread using postMessage() and the 'message' event.

data.q: Which global object is available inside a Web Worker?
data.explanation: Inside a Web Worker, 'self' refers to the global scope of the worker.

data.q: Can Web Workers access the DOM directly?
data.explanation: Web Workers cannot access the DOM directly; they can only communicate with the main thread.

data.q: Which method is used to terminate a Web Worker from the main thread?
data.explanation: The terminate() method stops a Web Worker from the main thread.

data.q: Which method is used inside a Web Worker to stop itself?
data.explanation: A worker can stop itself by calling self.close().

data.q: What type of data can be sent between the main thread and a Web Worker?
o: Any data that can be serialized
data.explanation: Web Workers use structured cloning, allowing most serializable data types to be sent.

data.q: Which API allows multiple workers to share memory more efficiently?
data.explanation: SharedArrayBuffer enables multiple workers to share memory efficiently.

data.q: What event is triggered in the main thread when a Web Worker sends a message?
data.explanation: The 'message' event is triggered when a Web Worker sends data back to the main thread.
